title: Harissa Chicken & Roast Vegetable Couscous — Traybake
hydrationTip: Serve with a glass of water or herbal tea alongside the meal, rather than in the recipe.
method: Preheat the oven to 200°C.
Toss the vegetables with olive oil and half the harissa paste on a baking tray.
Nestle the chicken breast on top, coat with the remaining harissa and season.
Roast for 20–25 minutes until the chicken is cooked through and the vegetables are caramelised.
Meanwhile, place couscous in a bowl, cover with just-boiled water, cover and leave to steam 5–10 minutes, then fluff with a fork.
Slice the chicken and serve over couscous with the roasted vegetables and chopped parsley.
swaps: Swap wholewheat couscous for quinoa or brown rice if gluten-free is needed.
Use tofu instead of chicken for a vegetarian version.
Stir through a spoon of Greek yoghurt at the table if dairy is tolerated.

title: Honey-Miso Salmon with Sesame Greens & Brown Rice
hydrationTip: Serve with a glass of water or herbal tea alongside the meal, rather than in the recipe.
method: Preheat the oven to 190°C.
Whisk miso, honey and a teaspoon of olive oil to make a glaze.
Place the salmon on a lined tray, brush with the glaze and set aside.
Toss the greens in the remaining olive oil and season lightly.
Roast salmon and greens for 12–15 minutes until the fish flakes and vegetables are tender.
Meanwhile, cook the rice or noodles according to packet instructions and drain.
Serve the salmon over the grains with the roasted greens and a sprinkle of sesame seeds.
swaps: Use tamari instead of miso if you need to avoid soy.
Swap brown rice for quinoa to increase protein and reduce cooking time.
Omit sesame seeds if allergic and garnish with chopped herbs instead.

Whisk miso, honey and a teaspoon of olive oil to make a glaze.
Place the salmon on a lined tray, brush with the glaze and set aside.
Toss the greens in the remaining olive oil and season lightly.
Roast salmon and greens for 12–15 minutes until the fish flakes and vegetables are tender.
Meanwhile, cook the rice or noodles according to packet instructions and drain.
Serve the salmon over the grains with the roasted greens and a sprinkle of sesame seeds.
swaps: Use tamari instead of miso if you need to avoid soy.
Swap brown rice for quinoa to increase protein and reduce cooking time.
Omit sesame seeds if allergic and garnish with chopped herbs instead.

title: Spinach & Ricotta Stuffed Chicken with Herby Potatoes
hydrationTip: Serve with a glass of water or herbal tea alongside the meal, rather than in the recipe.
method: Preheat the oven to 190°C.
In a small bowl mix ricotta, chopped spinach, garlic and lemon zest with a pinch of salt and pepper.
Open the butterflied chicken breast, spread the ricotta mixture inside, then fold and secure with cocktail sticks if needed.
Heat half the olive oil in an ovenproof pan and sear the chicken on each side until golden.
Add the prepared vegetables and remaining oil to the pan, tossing to coat.
Transfer to the oven and bake for 18–22 minutes, until the chicken is cooked through.
Meanwhile, boil or steam the potatoes or grains until tender, then drain.
Slice the chicken and serve over the carb base with the roasted vegetables.
swaps: Use lactose-free ricotta or a thick yoghurt cheese if needed.
Swap potatoes for butter beans for extra protein and fibre.
Omit garlic and increase herbs for a Low FODMAP-friendly version.

title: Mediterranean Cod with Olive Tapenade & Roast Tomatoes
hydrationTip: Serve with a glass of water or herbal tea alongside the meal, rather than in the recipe.
method: Preheat the oven to 190°C.
Mix chopped olives, capers, olive oil and lemon juice to make a quick tapenade.
Place the vegetables and potatoes or orzo (if using precooked) in a baking dish, drizzle with a little olive oil and season.
Lay the cod fillet on top and spread the tapenade over the fish.
Bake for 15–18 minutes until the cod flakes easily and the vegetables are tender.
If using orzo, cook it separately according to packet instructions, then spoon into bowls and top with the baked cod and vegetables.
swaps: Use salmon or haddock instead of cod.
Swap olives for semi-dried tomatoes if you dislike olives.
Serve over cannellini beans instead of grains for a gluten-free option.

title: Halloumi & Aubergine Traybake with Pomegranate & Mint
hydrationTip: Serve with a glass of water or herbal tea alongside the meal, rather than in the recipe.
method: Preheat the oven to 200°C.
Spread the vegetables on a tray, drizzle with olive oil, season and roast for 20 minutes.
Add the halloumi slices on top and return to the oven for 8–10 minutes until golden at the edges.
Meanwhile, place couscous in a bowl, cover with just-boiled water and leave 5–10 minutes before fluffing with a fork.
Serve the roasted vegetables and halloumi over couscous, scatter with pomegranate and mint.
swaps: Swap couscous for quinoa to make the dish gluten-free.
Use extra chickpeas instead of halloumi for a dairy-free version.
Replace pomegranate with chopped tomatoes when out of season.

title: Creamy Tuscan Chicken with Sun-Dried Tomatoes & Spinach
hydrationTip: Serve with a glass of water or herbal tea alongside the meal, rather than in the recipe.
method: Cook the pasta or gnocchi in boiling water according to packet instructions, then drain.
Heat olive oil in a large skillet over medium heat and brown the chicken slices.
Add garlic and sun-dried tomatoes and cook for 1–2 minutes until fragrant.
Pour in the stock and light cream, bring to a gentle simmer and reduce slightly.
Stir in the greens or vegetables until just wilted and the sauce has thickened.
Add the cooked pasta or gnocchi and toss to coat, sprinkling with Parmesan if using.
swaps: Use lactose-free cream and cheese if required.
Swap pasta for butter beans for extra fibre and fewer refined carbs.
Use extra stock instead of cream for a lighter sauce.

title: Saffron & Lemon Prawn Risotto with Peas
hydrationTip: Serve with a glass of water or herbal tea alongside the meal, rather than in the recipe.

ingredients.item: Hot low-salt vegetable or fish stock

method: Warm the stock in a small saucepan with the saffron.
Heat olive oil in a wide pan and gently cook the shallot until soft.
Stir in the rice and cook for 1–2 minutes until coated and slightly translucent at the edges.
Add a ladle of hot stock and stir until absorbed, repeating gradually for 15–18 minutes.
Add the vegetables and prawns for the last 5 minutes of cooking, stirring until the prawns are pink and cooked through.
Finish with lemon zest and Parmesan if using, adjusting seasoning to taste.
swaps: Use extra vegetables instead of prawns for a vegetarian version.
Swap Parmesan for nutritional yeast if dairy-free.
Use part white wine and part stock for a more traditional risotto.

title: Tofu Katsu with Crunchy Rainbow Slaw & Brown Rice
hydrationTip: Serve with a glass of water or herbal tea alongside the meal, rather than in the recipe.

ingredients.item: Egg, beaten (use plant milk for vegan)
Curry powder or katsu spice blend

method: Cook the brown rice or quinoa according to packet instructions, then drain.
Pat the tofu dry, dip in beaten egg (or plant milk), then coat in breadcrumbs mixed with half the curry powder.
Place on a lined tray, drizzle with olive oil and bake at 200°C for 15–18 minutes, turning once.
Meanwhile, finely shred the cabbage and other vegetables and toss with yoghurt, remaining curry powder and a pinch of salt.
Serve the crispy tofu slices over the rice with a mound of crunchy slaw.
swaps: Use chickpea flour batter instead of egg for a vegan coating.
Swap yoghurt for a tahini-lemon dressing for a different flavour profile.
Use cauliflower rice if you want to reduce carbs further.

title: Ras el Hanout Lamb & Chickpea Stew with Spinach
hydrationTip: Serve with a glass of water or herbal tea alongside the meal, rather than in the recipe.

ingredients.item: Ras el hanout or Moroccan spice mix

method: Heat olive oil in a casserole and brown the lamb on all sides, then remove to a plate.
Add onion and garlic to the pan and cook until softened.
Stir in the spice mix and toast for 1 minute.
Return the lamb to the pan with chickpeas, chopped tomatoes, stock and vegetables.
Bring to a gentle simmer, cover and cook for 45–60 minutes until the lamb is tender and the sauce has thickened.
Stir through spinach or extra greens at the end if using, and adjust seasoning.
swaps: Use turkey thigh or chicken thigh instead of lamb for a leaner version.
Serve over cauliflower rice or wholegrain couscous depending on carb needs.
Add extra chickpeas in place of meat for a vegetarian stew.

method: Heat olive oil in a casserole and brown the lamb on all sides, then remove to a plate.
Add onion and garlic to the pan and cook until softened.
Stir in the spice mix and toast for 1 minute.
Return the lamb to the pan with chickpeas, chopped tomatoes, stock and vegetables.
Bring to a gentle simmer, cover and cook for 45–60 minutes until the lamb is tender and the sauce has thickened.
Stir through spinach or extra greens at the end if using, and adjust seasoning.
swaps: Use turkey thigh or chicken thigh instead of lamb for a leaner version.
Serve over cauliflower rice or wholegrain couscous depending on carb needs.
Add extra chickpeas in place of meat for a vegetarian stew.

title: Baked Feta & Cherry Tomato Protein Pasta with Chicken
hydrationTip: Serve with a glass of water or herbal tea alongside the meal, rather than in the recipe.
method: Preheat the oven to 200°C.
Place cherry tomatoes and the feta block in a small baking dish.
Drizzle with olive oil, scatter over oregano and garlic, and roast for 20–25 minutes until the tomatoes blister.
Meanwhile, cook the pasta in boiling water according to packet instructions, then drain.
If using raw chicken, prawns or sausage, cook in a separate pan until fully cooked.
Stir the roasted feta and tomatoes into the pasta along with the protein and any spinach or chickpeas, loosening with a splash of pasta water if needed.
swaps: Use lentil or chickpea pasta to increase protein and fibre.
Swap feta for a vegan feta-style cheese if dairy-free.
Add chilli flakes for heat if you enjoy spice.

title: Lemon–Herb Chicken Breast & Courgette One-Pan — Lean Fuel (Budget)
hydrationTip: Serve with water or herbal tea if desired.

ingredients.item: stock or tinned tomatoes if needed for moisture

method: Heat the olive oil in a large pan over medium heat. Add the protein and cook until lightly browned.
Add the chopped vegetables and continue to sauté until softened and slightly caramelised.
Stir in the seasoning blend and coat everything well, allowing the spices to bloom.
Pour in stock or tinned tomatoes if required, bringing everything to a gentle simmer.
Reduce heat and cook until the protein is fully done and the flavours have come together.
Adjust seasoning with salt, pepper, lemon, or herbs. Serve hot.
swaps: Swap protein for tofu or beans.
Use seasonal vegetables to reduce cost.

method: Heat olive oil in a large frying pan or wok over medium-high heat.
Add onion and pepper and stir-fry for 3–4 minutes.
Add the soya milk and seeds and cook until lightly browned.
Tip in the rolled oats and leafy greens.
Season with soy, garlic, salt and pepper and cook for a further few minutes until the greens wilt.
Serve straight away in bowls.

title: Air-Fryer Lemon Herb Chicken & Potatoes
hydrationTip: Serve with a large glass of water or herbal tea. Aim for at least 300–500 ml fluid with this meal as part of your daily hydration target.
method: Preheat the air-fryer to 180°C.

Arrange in the air-fryer basket in a single layer where possible.

Serve hot with a green side salad or extra vegetables if you like.

Arrange in the air-fryer basket in a single layer where possible.
Cook for 12–18 minutes, shaking halfway, until the protein is cooked through and the edges are crisp.
Serve hot with a green side salad or extra vegetables if you like.

title: Slow-Cooker Beef & Lentil Chilli
hydrationTip: Serve with a large glass of water or herbal tea. Aim for at least 300–500 ml fluid with this meal as part of your daily hydration target.
method: Heat olive oil in a pan and brown the protein if using meat. Tip into the slow cooker.
Add onion, carrots, celery and garlic to the pan and soften briefly, then add to the slow cooker.
Stir in the legumes, tinned tomatoes, stock, paprika and herbs.
Cook on LOW for 6–8 hours or HIGH for 3–4 hours until everything is tender.
Serve with brown rice. Cool leftovers quickly and refrigerate or freeze in portions.

serving of chopped fruit or tomatoes depending on style
olive oil or nut butter depending on style
sea salt and pepper where appropriate

method: Add the main base ingredient to a bowl or lunch container.
Layer over the vegetables and fruit as appropriate for the style.
Sprinkle with seeds or nuts if using.
Drizzle with olive oil or nut butter.
Season if savoury and serve straight away or chill for later.

title: Smoky Paprika Chicken Meal Prep Bowls
hydrationTip: Serve with a large glass of water or herbal tea. Aim for at least 300–500 ml fluid with this meal as part of your daily hydration target.
method: Heat olive oil in a large pan and soften onion and garlic.
Add the chicken breast and cook until browned or heated through.
Stir in the mixed peppers and cook for a further few minutes.
Add the wholewheat pasta, smoked paprika and garlic and a splash of water if needed.
Simmer until everything is cooked and the flavours have developed.
Divide into 4 containers, cool quickly and refrigerate or freeze.
